conclusion: Let the centres of the three circular sections be O1 (top log A), O2 (left log B) and O3 (right log C).
A touches B and C, so O1O2 = O1O3 = 2R.
The given apex angle ∠O1 = 120° implies triangle O1O2O3 is isosceles with sides O1O2 = O1O3 = 2R and base O2O3 = 2R·√3 (by the law of cosines).
Place O2 at (–√3 R, 0), O3 at ( √3 R, 0). From O1O2 = 2R we get O1 at (0, R).
The line O2O1 (and O3O1) therefore makes an angle tan θ = (R)/(√3 R) ⇒ θ = 30° above the horizontal.

For log A there are only three forces: Its weight, mg, downward; Normal reaction N from B, acting along O2O1 (30° above the horizontal, toward O1); Normal reaction N from C, acting symmetrically along O3O1.
Vertical equilibrium of A: the vertical components of the two normals must balance its weight: 2·N sin 30° = mg ⇒ N = mg.

For log B the forces are: Weight mg downward; Ground normal N_g upward; Ground friction f horizontal (acting outward, i.e. to the left, because the contact with A pushes B inward); Normal from A (same magnitude N found above) acting along O2O1, i.e. 30° up from the horizontal, pointing toward O1 (to the right and up).
Resolve N into components: Horizontal N_h = N cos 30° = (√3/2) N; Vertical N_v = N sin 30° = (1/2) N.
Horizontal equilibrium of B: N_h – f = 0 ⇒ f = (√3/2) N.
Vertical equilibrium of B: N_g + N_v – mg = 0 ⇒ N_g = mg – (1/2) N.
The problem states that the logs on the ground are just about to slide and that the maximum static friction equals the kinetic (sliding) friction.
f = μ N_g, where μ is the (dynamic) coefficient of friction ground–log that we must find.
Insert N = mg (from step 1) into (2), (3) and (4).
